instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Afternoon!

I have a 820 - 00923 in at the moment for repair.

I was told it died once, then came good, then died again but before it did the battery came up with a please service message.

Once I got into it I found liquid damaged (only slight) around <CAPACITOR>C7097</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7096</CAPACITOR>, clean it up.

Once that was sorted I connected DC to the mac and preso! I got a healthy draw and a booting mac, although only with the battery disconnected.

I had a bit more of a look around to see what was happening, looked for any other issue & found nothing.

I then put it back together though this time it booted with the battery connected, except wasn't charging, and had the service battery message.

Tried a known good battery and same thing.

I follow the battery connection on the schematic and found <CAPACITOR>C6910</CAPACITOR> looked cooked - removed and the Mac wouldn't boot at all this time.

Replaced that cap and she booted but back at no charging / service battery message.

Thought perhaps because <CAPACITOR>C6910</CAPACITOR> was so cooked, I would try and replace <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. Have0 idea what I've done because now it's stuck at 5v not drawing 20v and not booting :(

I thought <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> needs to talk to SMC to tell it to give 20v so maybe my issue is there. Though I don't want to keep playing chip of fortune.

<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.7v which means U7000is getting the power it needs to turn on right? 

Any advice is appreciated

Cheers.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message: Do you get now correct voltage at L6900?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply mate,

I don't - I'm getting 2.1v @ L6900
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.8v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_BIAS</SIGNAL> = 3.8v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL> = 0.7v

Hope this helps.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Check if <RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR> has correct value (2.2 ohm).
Post <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> voltages.
Just in case, remove <RESISTOR>R6915</RESISTOR> and check again L6900 voltage.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6907</RESISTOR> is 2.6 ohm

<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>:
pin 1 =  0v
pin  2 = 5.18v
pin 3 = 3.8v 

L6900 = 2.2v with <RESISTOR>R6915</RESISTOR> removed.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Thanks mate - that sorted it & it now boots - though only without the battery attached. 

With battery attached it draws .042mA. Any idea what would cause the logicboard to think the battery needs a service, and then only works without it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message: You should test with known good battery first...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Hey mate

Replaced battery with known good, sits at .042mA with battery connected. 

When booted amp meter doesn't go to charging current, sits below 1A. 

Once mac is booted it says it's on 1% and to service the battery.

Hope this helps.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
So it now boots with battery connected?
Can you get more information about battery from System Report?

Check <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62 and their traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
It boots with the battery replaced, original battery no, though they both sit at .042amp. 

The original battery connected, the mac doesn't boot. 

With a new battery connected, it still sits at .042 though will boot when prompted, but doesn't get to charging current - sits below 1amp like there is no battery connected. 

<RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62 both at 1ohm and traces are fine. 

system report see a battery is there but it's not charging, recommends servicing. 

Is there something particular in the report that will help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
What is the macOS version installed?
People claimed on Internet about such kind of battery issue after upgrading to Big Sur.
You may try flashing full known good BIOS (clean ME).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Hey mate - customer had the issue pop up on it's own without being after an update. 

It's on 12.3 Monterey.

Is the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> the same as older macs for CLEAN ME? I need to use an aftermarket tool in order to do this? I don't have such tools, are you able to point me in the right direction. 

Tried looking it up and all I can find it how to remove EFI password, nothing about clean ME for 820 - 00923

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Thanks for that - I did find that myself, but I can't find clear details anywhere on how to actually flash, which is why I asked if there are tools I need to do this like Medusa... I can find the step by step for older boards like 820 - 00165 etc, but nothing for the 920 - 00928. 

Do I need such a tool? I legit can't find anything on youtube, forums etc 

Thanks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 - 00923 Service battery then died!
threads.message:
Medusa is the simplest way.
But you can remove the SPI chip and use classic USB programmer; with WSON to DIP adapter.
